Jason Rogers wrote:

> try {
>     articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
>     fail("Expected NoObjectFoundException);
> } catch (Exception e) {
>     assertSame(e.getClass(), NoObjectFoundException.class);
>     // or whatever else seems appropriate (eg. testing getMessage() or
> other attribute)
> }

Wow. I haven't seen that one before. It's growing on me, since it 
handles the "unexpected exception" failure without the whole 
Error/Failure confusion.

I should think, though, that 
assertTrue(NoObjectFoundException.class.isInstance(e)) is required, 
though, so that you can throw a subclass of the exception without 
failing the test. Perhaps that has just never been a problem for you.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
